questions.text: A 45-year-old man is brought to the emergency department after being found in a state of partial suspension with a rope around his neck. The medical team suspects hanging as the cause of death. During the autopsy, the forensic pathologist pays particular attention to the hyoid bone. The most likely finding in the hyoid bone in a case of hanging is a fracture at which of the following locations?

options.label: A
options.text: Junction of the outer one-third and inner two-thirds of the greater cornu

options.label: B
options.text: Junction of the outer two-thirds and inner one-third of the greater cornu

questions.correct_answer: A. Junction of the outer one-third and inner two-thirds of the greater cornu
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Junction of outer 1/3rd and inner 2/3rd of greater cornu

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option B: Junction of the outer two-thirds and inner one-third of the greater cornu - Less commonly involved in fractures due to hanging.
  • • Option B:
  • • Junction of the outer two-thirds and inner one-third of the greater cornu
  • • Less commonly involved
  • • Option C: Middle of the greater cornu - This area is stronger and less likely to be fractured in hanging.
  • • Option C:
  • • Middle of the greater cornu
  • • area is stronger and less likely to be fractured
  • • Option D: Middle of the body - The body of the hyoid bone is less commonly fractured in hanging compared to the junction of the greater cornu.
  • • Option D:
  • • Middle of the body
  • • body of the hyoid bone is less commonly fractured

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The common anatomical site of hyoid bone fracture in cases of hanging , is most often at the junction of the outer one-third and inner two-thirds of the greater cornu .
  • ➤ common anatomical site of hyoid bone fracture
  • ➤ hanging
  • ➤ junction of the outer one-third and inner two-thirds of the greater cornu
  • ➤ Ref - Reddy 33/e. Pg 345
  • ➤ Ref
  • ➤ - Reddy 33/e. Pg 345

questions.text: In forensic investigations of hanging deaths, the position of the body provides crucial information about the nature of the hanging. When a hanging is characterized by the feet touching the ground, it is classified as:
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Partial hanging

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option B: Complete hanging : This occurs when the entire weight of the body is suspended , with no support from the ground, which is not the case here.
  • • Option B:
  • • Complete hanging
  • • entire weight of the body is suspended
  • • Option C: Homicidal hanging : This classification is based on the manner of death (homicide) rather than the body's position.
  • • Option C:
  • • Homicidal hanging
  • • manner of death
  • • rather than the body's position.
  • • Option D: Suicidal hanging : This refers to the intent (suicide ) and not the physical position of the hanging.
  • • Option D:
  • • Suicidal hanging
  • • intent (suicide
  • • physical position of the hanging.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Partial hanging is characterized by the body being suspended with the feet touching the ground , differentiating it from complete hanging where the body is fully suspended.
  • ➤ Partial hanging
  • ➤ body being suspended with the feet touching the ground
  • ➤ Ref - Reddy 33/e. Pg 341
  • ➤ Ref
  • ➤ - Reddy 33/e. Pg 341

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman is found unresponsive in her apartment. The autopsy reveals bruising consistent with hand marks around her neck. The Forensic is explaining to the medical students that in cases of manual strangulation, the cause of death is typically due to the occlusion of what anatomical structure(s)?

options.label: C
options.text: Airway above the level of thyroid

options.label: D
options.text: Airway below the level of thyroid

questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Carotid arteries.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option B: Jugular vein - While compression of the jugular veins can contribute to death by preventing venous return from the brain , it is not the primary cause of death in manual strangulation.
  • • Option B:
  • • Jugular vein
  • • compression of the jugular veins can contribute to death by preventing venous return from the brain
  • • Option C: Airway above the level of thyroid - Compression of the airway can lead to asphyxia , but in manual strangulation, the occlusion of the carotid arteries is more immediately life-threatening.
  • • Option C:
  • • Airway above the level of thyroid
  • • Compression
  • • airway can lead to asphyxia
  • • Option D: Airway below the level of thyroid - Similar to option c, this can contribute to asphyxia but is not the primary mechanism of death in manual strangulation.
  • • Option D:
  • • Airway below the level of thyroid
  • • this can contribute to asphyxia

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Asphyxia produced by compression of the neck by human hands is called manual strangulation or Throttling. However, death occurs due to occlusion of carotid arteries. Occlusion of airway plays minor role .
  • ➤ Asphyxia
  • ➤ compression of the neck
  • ➤ human hands
  • ➤ manual strangulation
  • ➤ occlusion of carotid arteries.
  • ➤ Occlusion of airway plays minor role
  • ➤ Ref - Reddy 33/e. Pg 346
  • ➤ Ref
  • ➤ - Reddy 33/e. Pg 346

questions.text: A 50-year-old man, known to have a history of alcohol abuse, is found deceased at his dining table. He was eating hurriedly after consuming a significant amount of alcohol. The forensic expert is discussing the case with medical students and explains the possible causes of death in such a scenario. Which of the following is not a correct association in this case?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Caffey syndrome.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option B: Depressed gag reflex - In an alcohol-intoxicated individual, a depressed gag reflex is a plausible factor , as alcohol can depress the central nervous system, making accidental choking more likely.
  • • Option B:
  • • Depressed gag reflex
  • • alcohol-intoxicated individual,
  • • depressed gag reflex is a plausible factor
  • • Option C: Accidental choking - This is a likely cause of death in this scenario. Rapid eating, especially when combined with alcohol intoxication that depresses protective airway reflexes , can lead to choking.
  • • Option C:
  • • Accidental choking
  • • Rapid eating, especially when combined with alcohol intoxication that depresses protective airway reflexes

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ While in Caffey syndrome / Battered baby syndrome/ Child abuse syndrome, child is the one who has received repetitive physical injuries and the Cafe coronary is a condition in which a healthy but grossly intoxicated person, who begins a meal, suddenly turns blue , coughs violently, then collapses and dies due to depressed gag reflex and accidental choking.
  • ➤ Caffey syndrome
  • ➤ child is the one who has received repetitive physical injuries
  • ➤ healthy but grossly intoxicated person, who begins a meal, suddenly turns blue
  • ➤ Ref - Reddy 33/e. Pg 365
  • ➤ Ref - Reddy 33/e. Pg 365

questions.text: A group of students are learning about the post-mortem changes in drowning victims. The instructor emphasizes the importance of understanding the sequence of skin changes for accurate assessment in drowning cases. Which among the following is the correct sequence of skin changes in drowning?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Wrinkling-Soddening-Bleaching-Degloving

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Washerwoman's hand-It is seen in case of drowning . The skin of the palms and soles are characterized by thickening, bleached, sodden, and corrugated appearance .
  • • Washerwoman's hand-It is seen in case of drowning
  • • skin of the palms and soles
  • • thickening, bleached, sodden, and corrugated appearance
  • • Time of appearance after submersion:
  • • Wrinkling - After 3 hr of immersion
  • • Wrinkling - After 3 hr of immersion
  • • Wrinkling
  • • Soddening (filled with water) - After 12 hrs of immersion Bleaching - After 36 hrs of immersion Degloving (Peeling)- after 72 hours of immersion
  • • Soddening (filled with water) - After 12 hrs of immersion
  • • Soddening
  • • Bleaching - After 36 hrs of immersion
  • • Bleaching
  • • Degloving (Peeling)- after 72 hours of immersion
  • • Degloving
  • • It is first seen on the fingertips in two to four hours and spreads to the palm and the backs of the fingers , and the back of the hand , in that order in about twenty-four hours . Similar progress and changes are seen in the skin of the foot, but when shoes are worn, it takes almost twice as long.
  • • first seen on the fingertips in two to four hours
  • • spreads to the palm and the backs of the fingers
  • • back of the hand
  • • twenty-four hours

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The correct sequence of skin changes in drowning, which typically follows the order of wrinkling, soddening, bleaching, and finally degloving/ peeling .
  • ➤ wrinkling, soddening, bleaching, and finally degloving/ peeling

  • ➤ Ref

questions.text: A forensic resident is presenting a case of a drowning victim to her colleagues. The victim was found unconscious in a swimming pool and was later pronounced dead. The autopsy revealed significant findings in the lungs. The resident discusses the development of 'Edema Aquosum' or immersion pulmonary edema in drowning cases. Which scenario is most likely associated with the development of Edema Aquosum?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Antemortem unconscious drowning

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A: Postmortem drowning - Postmortem submersion does not involve active inhalation of water, as the victim is already dead and lacks respiratory function. Therefore, the development of significant pulmonary edema is less likely in postmortem drowning
  • • Option A:
  • • Postmortem drowning
  • • Postmortem submersion
  • • Option C: Antemortem conscious drowning - Emphysema aquosum : When a person submerges in conscious state and due to violent respiratory effort following increased pressure due to forced expiration ballooning of the lungs occur and a column of froth is formed in the air passage.
  • • Option C:
  • • Antemortem conscious drowning
  • • Emphysema aquosum
  • • submerges in conscious state
  • • violent respiratory effort
  • • increased pressure due to forced expiration ballooning of the lungs occur

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ When the person is unconscious at the time of drowning, edema aquosum develops . It is a state of mere flooding of lungs with airless water and no formation of froth . Emphysema aquosum develops only when the conscious victim of drowning struggles for survival.
  • ➤ unconscious at the time of drowning, edema aquosum develops
  • ➤ mere flooding of lungs
  • ➤ airless water
  • ➤ no formation of froth
  • ➤ Ref - Reddy 33/e. Pg 369
  • ➤ Ref - Reddy 33/e. Pg 369

questions.text: During an autopsy of a woman who was found dead in a river, the forensic pathologist notices the presence of water in the woman's feet. The medical students observing the autopsy are asked about the significance of this finding. What does the presence of water in the feet during autopsy typically indicate?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Prolonged immersion in water.

Explanation:

  • • Option A: Antemortem drowning - While this could be a possibility, the presence of water in the feet alone is not specific enough to confirm antemortem drowning .
  • • Option A:

  • • the presence of water in the feet
  • • confirm antemortem drowning
  • • Option B: Postmortem drowning - This term is usually used to describe a body that has been immersed after death ; the presence of water in the feet is not specific to this.
  • • Option B:
  • • Postmortem drowning
  • • a body that has been immersed after death

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Washerwoman's hand/feet : Skin of the limbs becomes sodden, thickened, wrinkled and white in color (fingertip-2 hrs, back of hand-24 hrs, palm & sole - 2 days, degloving-3 to 4 days). Not a specific sign of drowning. It occurs due to prolonged immersion in water .
  • ➤ Washerwoman's hand/feet
  • ➤ Skin of the limbs becomes sodden, thickened, wrinkled and white in color
  • ➤ prolonged immersion in water
  • ➤ Ref - Reddy 33/e. Pg 368
  • ➤ Ref
  • ➤ - Reddy 33/e. Pg 368

questions.explanation:

  • • Suicidal
  • • It is rare
  • • Option D: Homicidal - Choking as a mode of infanticide may be caused by stuffing a wad of paper or cloth into the pharynx or larynx . It is very rare and i practicable only when the victim is suffering from disability or disease.

questions.text: A decomposed body is found in a room. Upon examination, the forensic resident notes that the face shows postmortem purging, but a ligature mark on the neck is still visible. The resident asks the medical students about the most likely cause of death in this case. What could be the possible cause of death?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Hanging

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A: Manual strangulation - OR throttling : When human fingers, palms or hands are used to compress the neck , so no ligature mark.
  • • Option A:
  • • Manual strangulation
  • • throttling
  • • human fingers, palms or hands are used to compress the neck
  • • Option B: Ligature strangulation - When ligature material is used to compress the neck . Could potentially leave a mark, but the pattern may differ from that seen in hanging. As it is not dry and hard, hence it will fade in decomposed body.
  • • Option B:
  • • Ligature strangulation
  • • ligature material is used to compress the neck
  • • Option D: Mugging - Holding the neck of victim in the bend of the elbow or knee of the assailant . It is an attack, usually from behind, and may leave no external or internal injury mark. It is also known as chokehold. This hold is not permitted in wrestling, because of its danger.
  • • Option D:
  • • Mugging
  • • Holding the
  • • neck of victim in the bend of the elbow or knee of the assailant

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The presence of a visible ligature mark on the neck , even in an advanced decomposed body is indicative of death by hanging.
  • ➤ presence of a visible ligature mark on the neck
  • ➤ death by hanging.
  • ➤ Ref - Reddy 33/e. Pg 338
  • ➤ Ref - Reddy 33/e. Pg 338

questions.text: A Forensic Expert is examining a body found with a ligature around the neck in an atypical position. Notably, there is dribbling of saliva on the body. He asks the medical students observing the autopsy about the expected pattern of saliva in cases of atypical hanging. Where is dribbling of saliva typically seen in a case of atypical hanging?
questions.correct_answer: B. Opposite the site of knot
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Opposite the site of knot

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A: Towards the site of knot - This is less common, as gravity tends to draw the saliva away from the higher side where the knot is located.
  • • Option A:
  • • Towards the site of knot
  • • less common, as gravity tends to draw the saliva away
  • • Option C: Both the angles - Saliva typically dribbles down the lowest point due to gravity , which is usually opposite to the knot.
  • • Option C:
  • • Both the angles
  • • Saliva typically dribbles down the lowest point
  • • gravity
  • • Option D: No salivary stain found - Salivary stains are often present in hanging cases due to loss of control over salivary glands.
  • • Option D:
  • • No salivary stain found
  • • Salivary stains are often present in hanging cases

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In cases of atypical hanging , the dribbling of saliva is typically observed opposite to the site of the knot , influenced by the position of the body and the effects of gravity.
  • ➤ atypical hanging
  • ➤ dribbling of saliva is typically observed opposite to the site of the knot

questions.text: A forensic resident is examining the autopsy findings of a deceased individual who was discovered under suspicious circumstances. The investigation suggests possible foul play, and he is looking for specific clues to determine the cause of death. Among the findings, he notices fractures in the neck area. Which of the following autopsy findings is not commonly associated with ligature strangulation, raising the possibility of a different cause of death?

options.label: C
options.text: Bruising in the strap muscles of neck

options.label: D
options.text: Deep congestion of face with petechial hemorrhage

questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Fracture of hyoid bone

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option B: Fracture of thyroid cartilage - is more common esp. in one or both the superior horns .
  • • Option B:
  • • Fracture of thyroid cartilage

  • • Option C: Bruising in the strap muscles of neck - Extensive bruising and laceration of adjacent muscles of the neck.
  • • Option C:
  • • Extensive bruising and laceration
  • • Option D: Deep congestion of face with petechial hemorrhage - Severe engorgement and hemorrhage into the tissue in and above the area of compression.
  • • Option D:
  • • Severe engorgement and hemorrhage into the tissue

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Ligature strangulation is characterized by a transverse ligature mark encircling the neck, peri-ligature injuries, intense congestion, and signs of struggle . Internally, it is marked by severe tissue engorgement, bruising of neck muscles, and often the fracture of the thyroid cartilage, especially its superior horn.

questions.text: A Medical officer is conducting an autopsy on a victim of a suspicious death. He is examining various findings to determine the cause of death. In cases of violent asphyxia, which of the following structures should be open at last?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Neck

  • • Abdominal cavity
  • • not specific to violent asphyxia
  • • Option C: Cranial cavity : Important in traumatic deaths , but in violent asphyxia, neck examination is more crucial.
  • • Option C:
  • • Cranial cavity
  • • traumatic deaths

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Examining the neck

questions.text: A 35-year-old man was found dead in a lake. On forensic examination, the medical examiner noted certain findings to determine whether the death was due to antemortem drowning or postmortem submersion. Which of the following findings is most indicative of antemortem drowning?

options.label: D
options.text: Weeds and grass tightly held in the hands

questions.correct_answer: D. Weeds and grass tightly held in the hands
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Weeds and grass tightly held in the hands

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A: Washerwoman's hand - This refers to the pruney appearance of the skin after prolonged exposure to water and can occur in both antemortem and postmortem cases.
  • • Option A:
  • • refers to the pruney appearance of the skin
  • • Option B: Water in the stomach - While water in the stomach can be seen in drowning victims , it is not conclusive of antemortem drowning , as water can enter the stomach postmortem in submerged bodies. But if Mud and algae in stomach and intestine, then this is sure sign of antemortem drowning.
  • • Option B:
  • • seen in drowning victims
  • • not conclusive of antemortem drowning
  • • Option C. Cutis Anserina : Cutis anserina, also known as "goose flesh" or "goose bumps," can be seen in both antemortem and postmortem drowning cases. It is characterized by a puckered appearance of the skin with hair standing erect due to the contraction of the erector pili muscles.
  • • Option C. Cutis Anserina
  • • In cases of antemortem drowning, cutis anserina can occur due to the body's physiological response to the cold water. When a person is alive and submerged in cold water, the erector pili muscles contract in response to the cold, causing the hair to stand on end.
  • • Cutis anserina can also be observed in postmortem drowning cases. After death, rigor mortis sets in, affecting all skeletal muscles, including the erector pili muscles. This postmortem rigidity can cause the hair to stand on end, giving the appearance of cutis anserina

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Weeds and grass tightly held in the hands : This is a classic sign of struggle before death . It suggests the victim was alive and trying to save himself, possibly grabbing vegetation in panic—a strong vital reaction indicating antemortem drowning .
  • ➤ Weeds and grass tightly held in the hands
  • ➤ sign of struggle before death
  • ➤ vital reaction
  • ➤ drowning
  • ➤ Ref - Reddy 33/e. Pg 368
  • ➤ Ref - Reddy 33/e. Pg 368

questions.text: A patient was found unresponsive near a pool and later pronounced dead. Despite resuscitation efforts, no significant water was found in the lungs upon autopsy. Which of the following is the most likely cause of death in this scenario, often described as "dry drowning"?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Laryngeal spasm

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A: Acute Pulmonary edema - While pulmonary edema can occur in drowning, it is not the primary cause in dry drowning , which is characterized by minimal water in the lungs.
  • • Option A:
  • • Acute Pulmonary edema
  • • pulmonary edema can occur in drowning, it is not the primary cause in dry drowning
  • • Option B: Myocardial infarction - This is an unlikely cause of death in the context of drowning, especially in younger individuals without underlying heart disease.
  • • Option B:
  • • Myocardial infarction
  • • unlikely cause of death
  • • Option D: Cerebral hypoxia - While cerebral hypoxia is a consequence of prolonged asphyxia, in the context of dry drowning, the direct cause leading to hypoxia is laryngeal spasm.
  • • Option D:
  • • Cerebral hypoxia
  • • consequence of prolonged asphyxia,

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Laryngeal spasm as the primary cause of death in cases of dry drowning , which is characterized by airway obstruction due to reflexive closure of the vocal cords in response to water contact with the larynx.
  • ➤ Laryngeal spasm as the primary cause of death in cases of dry drowning
  • ➤ airway obstruction
  • ➤ Ref - Reddy 33/e. Pg 373
  • ➤ Ref
  • ➤ - Reddy 33/e. Pg 373

questions.text: During the autopsy of a victim suspected to have drowned in freshwater, alterations in the lung surfactant were noted. What changes occur to pulmonary surfactant in freshwater drowning?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Denatured

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option B: Diluted - This is observed in sea water drowning , surfactant are diluted and washed away .
  • • Option B:
  • • Diluted
  • • sea water drowning
  • • surfactant are diluted
  • • washed away
  • • Pathophysiology of Sea water drowning –
  • • Due to the high salinity , water is drawn from the blood into the lung tissue , and produces severe pulmonary oedema, and hypernatremia. This causes hemoconcentration. Heart failure may occur due to myocardial anoxia and increased viscosity of blood. Slow death occurs from asphyxia.
  • • Due to the high salinity , water is drawn from the blood into the lung tissue , and produces severe pulmonary oedema, and hypernatremia. This causes hemoconcentration.
  • • Due to the high salinity
  • • water is drawn from the blood into the lung tissue
  • • Heart failure may occur due to myocardial anoxia and increased viscosity of blood. Slow death occurs from asphyxia.
  • • Heart failure may occur due to myocardial anoxia

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:

questions.text: In a forensic lecture, the instructor discusses the Gettler test, a diagnostic tool used in the investigation of drowning deaths. This test is based on the premise that during drowning , especially in saltwater , the absorption of water leads to changes in the electrolyte balance in the blood , which is reflected in the chloride content.

Under Sec. 354-C IPC, voyeurism is a punishable offence, for first offence imprisonment from 1–3 years and fine (cognizable and bailable), and for 2nd offence, imprisonment is for 3–7 years and fine (cognizable and non-bailable).

questions.text: In forensic investigations, particularly in suspected drowning cases, the diatom test is crucial to establish the cause of death. Diatoms are microscopic algae present in water bodies and can enter the body during drowning. Considering the distribution of diatoms in a drowned body, which of the following is considered the ideal sample for a diatom test?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Femur (thigh bone)

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The femur (thigh bone) is considered the ideal sample for a diatom test in suspected antemortem drowning cases . This helps to confirm whether the individual was alive at the time of submersion.
  • • femur (thigh bone)
  • • ideal sample
  • • diatom test in suspected antemortem drowning cases
  • • Diatom test –
  • • Diatom test –
  • • Diatoms belong to the class Bacillariophyceae and are microscopic unicellular algae which secrete silicon skeletons called frustules. They are chemically inert and almost indestructible, resistant to strong acids. During drowning, diatoms (size up to 60 μ) enter the circulation via the lungs through the ruptured alveolar walls, lymph channels and pulmonary veins into the left heart and then into general circulation, when the person is alive. The presence of diatoms in the lung substance, blood stream, brain, liver, kidneys , sternum, bone marrow of femur (best site for analysis) or humerus or in the skeletal muscle has been claimed to be suggestive proof of antemortem drowning. Since diatoms resist putrefaction, diatom tests may have some value in examination of decomposed bodies. The test is negative in dead bodies thrown in water and in dry drowning. A water sample is collected at the time of body retrieval in a clean container and similarity of different species of diatom is compared. Interpretation - The presence of diatoms supports the diagnosis of drowning, while the absence of diatoms does not exclude it as a cause. The test is limited by the difficulty of excluding the possibility of environmental contamination, Still, the diatom test is considered as the ‘gold standard’ for diagnosis of ‘typical drowning.
  • • Diatoms belong to the class Bacillariophyceae and are microscopic unicellular algae which secrete silicon skeletons called frustules. They are chemically inert and almost indestructible, resistant to strong acids.

  • • During drowning, diatoms (size up to 60 μ) enter the circulation via the lungs through the ruptured alveolar walls, lymph channels and pulmonary veins into the left heart and then into general circulation, when the person is alive.
  • • During drowning, diatoms (size up to 60 μ) enter the circulation via the lungs
  • • The presence of diatoms in the lung substance, blood stream, brain, liver, kidneys , sternum, bone marrow of femur (best site for analysis) or humerus or in the skeletal muscle has been claimed to be suggestive proof of antemortem drowning.
  • • lung substance, blood stream, brain, liver, kidneys
  • • sternum, bone marrow of femur (best site for analysis)
  • • or humerus
  • • Since diatoms resist putrefaction, diatom tests may have some value in examination of decomposed bodies.
  • • The test is negative in dead bodies thrown in water and in dry drowning.
  • • test is negative in dead bodies
  • • A water sample is collected at the time of body retrieval in a clean container and similarity of different species of diatom is compared.
  • • Interpretation - The presence of diatoms supports the diagnosis of drowning, while the absence of diatoms does not exclude it as a cause.
  • • Interpretation -
  • • The test is limited by the difficulty of excluding the possibility of environmental contamination, Still, the diatom test is considered as the ‘gold standard’ for diagnosis of ‘typical drowning.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ The femur (thigh bone) is the ideal sample for diatom testing in suspected drowning cases to confirm if the person was alive during submersion, as it provides a reliable and less contaminated source for detecting diatoms.

questions.text: The forensic analysis of neck injuries is a vital component in determining the cause of death. The hyoid bone, a U-shaped bone in the neck, can fracture under certain circumstances. In which of the following situations is a hyoid bone fracture most commonly seen?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Throttling

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A: Hanging : While the hyoid bone can be affected in hangings , fractures are less common because the force is usually distributed along the ligature rather than directly on the hyoid.
  • • Option A:
  • • Hanging
  • • hyoid bone can be affected in hangings
  • • fractures are less common
  • • Option B: Strangulation by ligature : Similar to hanging , the force is distributed by the ligature and does not typically directly impact the hyoid bone to cause a fracture.
  • • Option B:
  • • Strangulation by ligature
  • • hanging
  • • the force is distributed by the ligature
  • • Option D: Burking : This involves a combination of suffocation and crushing of the chest . While it may involve neck compression, the mechanism is less likely to specifically cause hyoid bone fracture compared to throttling.
  • • Option D:
  • • Burking
  • • combination of suffocation and crushing of the chest

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Inward compression fracture of hyoid bone is the most diagnostic finding of throttling, which differentiates it from other causes of death such as hanging or strangulation by ligature. In contrast, hanging, whether by ligature or suspension, typically does not exert direct pressure on the hyoid bone . Strangulation by ligature and Burking (smothering and compressing the chest) are less likely to cause direct trauma to the hyoid bone compared to throttling.
  • ➤ Inward compression fracture of hyoid bone is the most diagnostic finding of throttling,
  • ➤ does not exert direct pressure on the hyoid bone
  • ➤ Sequence of hyoid bone fracture: Throttling > hanging > ligature strangulation .
  • ➤ Throttling > hanging > ligature strangulation
  • ➤ Ref - Reddy 33/e. Pg 341
  • ➤ Ref
  • ➤ - Reddy 33/e. Pg 341

questions.text: A 55-year-old male prisoner, sentenced to death, underwent execution by judicial hanging. The execution was performed with a calculated drop length. Upon autopsy, the forensic expert observed a specific finding with no signs of struggle or defensive injuries. Considering the mechanism of death in judicial hangings and the autopsy findings, what is the most likely cause of death in this case?
questions.correct_answer: C. Fracture of upper cervical vertebra
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Fracture of upper cervical vertebra

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A: Airway occlusion : While this can occur in hangings , it is not the primary mechanism in judicial hanging , which aims for a quick fracture of the neck.
  • • Option A:
  • • Airway occlusion
  • • can occur in hangings
  • • it is not the primary mechanism
  • • judicial hanging
  • • Option B: Vasovagal shock : This is a less likely primary cause of death in judicial hangings , as the mechanism is designed to be quick and efficient.
  • • Option B:
  • • Vasovagal shock
  • • primary cause of death in judicial hangings
  • • Option D: Coma : Coma may result from the injury , but it is not the primary mechanism of death in judicial hanging.
  • • Option D:
  • • Coma
  • • result from the injury

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Judicial hanging typically results in death due to the fracture of the upper cervical vertebrae , leading to immediate unconsciousness and rapid death due to spinal cord injury and brainstem disruption.
  • ➤ Judicial hanging typically results in death due to the fracture of the upper cervical vertebrae
  • ➤ Ref - Reddy 33/e. Pg 339
  • ➤ Ref
  • ➤ - Reddy 33/e. Pg 339

questions.text: A 35-year-old man was found dead in a remote area near his farm. The local medical officer was called to the scene and noted a piece of cloth tied tightly around the man's neck with sticks inserted into the knot, applying a compressive force. There were no other signs of struggle or injury. The medical officer knows this finding is significant and characteristic of a specific type of asphyxial death. Which type of asphyxia does this scenario most likely represent?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Bansdola

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A: Garrotting : Ligature material is twisted with help of a lever . It is a special type of garroting where the ligature material is an iron collar twisted by a lever . It was a method of judicial execution in Spain . Image below shows Garrotting:
  • • Option A:
  • • Garrotting
  • • Ligature material
  • • twisted with help of a lever
  • • iron collar twisted by a lever
  • • Spain
  • • Option C: Throttling : When constriction is produced by the pressure of the fingers and palms upon the throat , it is called throttling.
  • • Option C:
  • • Throttling
  • • constriction is produced by the pressure of the fingers and palms upon the throat
  • • Option D: Mugging : When strangulation is brought about by compressing the throat with a foot, knee, bend of elbow , or some other solid substances, it is known as mugging (stranglehold).
  • • Option D:
  • • Mugging
  • • strangulation is brought about by compressing the throat with a foot, knee, bend of elbow

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Bansdola is a form of asphyxia where a piece of cloth or rope is tied around the neck and sticks are used to twist and tighten it , resulting in strangulation. This method is particularly noted for the use of sticks to apply compressive force.
  • ➤ Bansdola is a form of asphyxia where a piece of cloth or rope is tied around the neck
  • ➤ sticks are used to twist and tighten it

  • ➤ Ref

questions.text: A 48-year-old man was found deceased in his home following a heated argument with his brother over property division. The casualty medical officer at a district hospital observed the deceased during the post-mortem examination. A radiological image revealed a distinct finding in the mandibular area, indicative of significant trauma. Given the context of a familial dispute and the radiological findings, what is the most likely cause of death?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Throttling

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option B: Burking : It does not cause hyoid # or any other neck injury , as it is compression of chest and closure of mouth and nose.
  • • Option B:
  • • Burking
  • • hyoid # or any other neck injury
  • • Option C: Ligature Strangulation : Hyoid # in LS is rare . It is much more common in MS.
  • • Option C:
  • • Ligature Strangulation
  • • Hyoid # in LS is rare
  • • Option D: Hanging : Hyoid # in hanging is outward # as shown below:
  • • Option D:
  • • Hanging
  • • Hyoid # in hanging is outward

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The presence of an inward fracture of the hyoid bone is most commonly associated with throttling . Burking does not typically result in neck injuries , ligature strangulation rarely causes hyoid fractures, and hanging generally results in outward hyoid fractures. Understanding the pattern of neck injuries is crucial in forensic evaluations to determine the mechanism of death.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man is brought to the emergency department of a medical college by paramedics after being found unresponsive in his home. The casualty medical officer notes that the patient has no pulse and is pronounced dead on arrival. The forensic expert conducts an autopsy and observes an oblique ligature mark located above the level of the thyroid cartilage. The subcutaneous tissue underneath the ligature mark appears white and glistening. No other signs of struggle or trauma are present on the body. Considering these autopsy findings, what is the most likely cause of death?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Hanging

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A: Throttling : Throttling, or manual strangulation , involves the use of hands to compress the neck , which can cause a variety of injuries including intimal tears , due to the direct and forceful nature of the trauma applied to the neck structures, so do not have any ligature mark
  • • Option A:
  • • Throttling
  • • manual strangulation
  • • use of hands to compress the neck
  • • cause a variety of injuries including intimal tears
  • • Option B: Ligature strangulation : While ligature strangulation could potentially cause an intimal tear, it is more commonly associated with circumferential compression of the neck with a ligature mark, but the features are very different and is mentioned above
  • • Option B:
  • • Ligature strangulation
  • • cause an intimal tear, it is more commonly associated with circumferential compression of the neck
  • • Option C: Gagging : Gagging is a form of asphyxia which results from pushing a gag (rolled up cloth or paper balls) into the mouth, sufficiently deep to block the pharynx. It combines the features of smothering and choking. So, it doesnot have any ligature mark
  • • Option C:
  • • Gagging
  • • form of asphyxia which results from pushing a gag

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The question aims to assess the ability to differentiate between various causes of asphyxial death based on autopsy findings . In this scenario, the oblique ligature mark above the thyroid cartilage, with specific subcutaneous tissue appearance and the absence of other injuries, points towards hanging as the cause of death.
  • ➤ ability to differentiate between various causes of asphyxial death based on autopsy findings
  • ➤ Ref - Reddy 33/e. Pg 338-341
  • ➤ Ref
  • ➤ - Reddy 33/e. Pg 338-341

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman is found unresponsive on a beach and is brought to the nearest district hospital by the lifeguard. On examination by the medical officer, the patient is pronounced dead. During the external examination of the body, the medical officer notes the presence of fine, copious white froth at the mouth and nostrils that resembles shaving lather. The body shows no signs of significant external injuries, and there is no evidence of drug use or paraphernalia at the scene. Given the clinical findings and the circumstances in which the body was found, what is the most likely cause of death?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Drowning

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option B: Hanging : This would more likely present with ligature marks on the neck and would not cause the frothy exudate seen in drowning.
  • • Option B:
  • • Hanging
  • • ligature marks on the neck
  • • Option C: Morphine poisoning : Overdose may lead to pulmonary edema , but the froth is usually not as fine & copious or 'shaving-lather' like as seen in drowning and would often be accompanied by evidence of drug use.
  • • Option C:
  • • Morphine poisoning
  • • Overdose
  • • pulmonary edema
  • • froth is usually not as fine & copious or 'shaving-lather'
  • • Option D: Strangulation : Similar to hanging, would present with signs of neck compression and would not produce the characteristic (fine & copious) frothy exudate seen in drowning.
  • • Option D:
  • • Strangulation
  • • hanging, would present with signs of neck compression

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The goal is to recognize the significance of external findings in determining the cause of death . The presence of frothy exudate at the mouth and nostrils , especially when associated with a water setting , is highly suggestive of drowning and should prompt further investigation consistent with this cause of death.
  • ➤ recognize the significance of external findings in determining the cause of death
  • ➤ frothy exudate at the mouth and nostrils
  • ➤ associated with a water setting
  • ➤ suggestive of drowning
  • ➤ Ref - Reddy 33/e. Pg 367
  • ➤ Ref
  • ➤ - Reddy 33/e. Pg 367

questions.text: A body is found by a fisherman in a freshwater lake in a remote area. The local medical officer is called to the scene to examine the body. During the external examination, he notes that the hair on the body's arms is erect, and there are no other visible signs of trauma or struggle. The body is otherwise well-preserved with no evidence of decomposition. Given the findings, which of the following is the most likely condition indicated by the image?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Immersion in water

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A: Antemortem Drowning and B. Postmortem Drowning : Cutis Anserina can be seen in both antemortem and postmortem drowning , hence it is not a specific sign of antemortem or postmortem drowning.
  • • Option A:
  • • Antemortem Drowning and B. Postmortem Drowning
  • • Cutis Anserina
  • • both antemortem and postmortem drowning
  • • Option D: Electrocution in water : Since electrical injury causes burns, blisters and wounds on the skin instead of cutis anserine, this can't be the answer.
  • • Option D:
  • • Electrocution in water
  • • electrical injury causes burns, blisters and wounds on the skin

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ "Goose flesh," "Goose pimples," or Cutis anserin is a temporary condition characterized by the erection of body hairs due to the contraction of small muscles at the base of each hair follicle . This reaction is most commonly a physiological response to cold. This can occur in both antemortem and postmortem conditions involving immersion in cold water.
  • ➤ "Goose flesh," "Goose pimples," or Cutis anserin is a temporary condition characterized by the erection of body hairs
  • ➤ contraction of small muscles at the base of each hair follicle
  • ➤ Re f - Reddy 33/e. Pg 368
  • ➤ Re f -
  • ➤ Reddy 33/e. Pg 368
